subtitle: Clear, simple explanations to help you understand income tax filing in Bangladesh.
ctaSubtitle: Every taxpayer's situation is different. If you're unsure about your obligations or want peace of mind, speak with one of our tax experts today.

questions.question: Who is legally required to file an income tax return in Bangladesh?
questions.answer:
You are required to file a tax return if any of the following applies to you:

• Your total income exceeds the tax-free threshold
• You have a Tax Identification Number (TIN)
• You own a car or property within a city corporation area
• You hold a trade license or operate a business
• You are a company director
• You fall under any other mandatory filing category set by the NBR

If you're unsure whether you qualify, our experts can quickly assess your situation.

questions.question: When should I file my tax return, and how often is filing required?
questions.answer:
Tax returns must be filed once every assessment year.

For individual taxpayers, the deadline is typically 30 November of each assessment year.

Filing on time helps you avoid penalties and unnecessary complications.

questions.question: What happens if I fail to file my tax return on time?
questions.answer:
Late filing may result in:

• A minimum penalty of BDT 1,000
• 10% of the last assessed tax (where applicable)
• An additional BDT 50 per day for continued delay
• Complications in renewing trade licenses or obtaining financial facilities

Filing on time protects you from avoidable penalties and stress.

questions.question: What are the consequences of providing incorrect or incomplete information?
questions.answer:
Providing false or incomplete information may be treated as concealment of income.

This can lead to:

• Financial penalties
• Additional tax on concealed income
• In serious cases, legal consequences

Accurate filing is essential. Our team ensures your return is prepared correctly and in full compliance with the law.

questions.question: What types of income must be declared in a tax return?
questions.answer:
All sources of taxable income must be declared, including:

• Salary
• Business, professional, or freelancing income
• Rental income
• Interest, dividends, and capital gains
• Any other taxable receipts

If you earn it and it is taxable, it must be reported.

questions.question: Do I need to file if tax was already deducted at source (TDS)?
questions.answer:
Yes.

Even if your employer has deducted tax at source, you must still file a return if:

• Your income exceeds the tax-free threshold, or
• You fall under any mandatory filing category

TDS does not remove your legal obligation to file.

questions.question: Do I need to file taxes if I only have salary income?
questions.answer:
Yes — if your salary exceeds the tax-free threshold or if you hold a TIN.

You may not need to file only if:

• Your income is below the threshold, AND
• You do not fall under any mandatory filing category.

When in doubt, it is safer to verify your status.

questions.question: Do I need to declare income from freelancing or side jobs?
questions.answer:
Yes.

Income from freelancing, outsourcing, online work, or part-time jobs is fully taxable and must be declared in your return.

All legal income sources must be reported.

questions.question: Do I need to file taxes if I only earn rental income?
questions.answer:
Yes.

Rental income is taxable and must be included in your tax return if it exceeds the applicable limits or falls under mandatory filing rules.

questions.question: What documents are required to file a tax return?
questions.answer:
Typically, you will need:

• TIN and NID
• Salary certificate or proof of income
• Bank statements (for interest or other income)
• Rental agreements (if applicable)
• Investment or profit statements
• Asset and liability information
• Previous year's return (if available)

Our team will guide you through exactly what is required in your case.

questions.question: What is the difference between an e-TIN and a TIN certificate?
questions.answer:
e-TIN is your actual 12-digit Taxpayer Identification Number issued electronically.

TIN Certificate is the official document showing your TIN.

They represent the same registration — one is the number, the other is the proof.

questions.question: Is it mandatory to update my TIN information if my address or profession changes?
questions.answer:
Yes.

You must keep your TIN profile updated with accurate address, profession, and personal details.

Outdated or incorrect information may cause future complications or penalties.

questions.question: How can I correct mistakes after submitting my tax return?
questions.answer:
If you discover an error after submission, you can file a Revised Return.

This must be submitted before the tax authority completes the assessment.

Unintentional mistakes can be corrected. However, deliberate concealment remains punishable.
